Though this occurs at shutdown, could it occur in other situations too?
For example another thread could use wakeup() against this thread - though I think we do?
I'm wondering if we should pause and retry ... though at shutdown I'd be concerned we wait too long
If we really only think wakeup will be at shutdown then this handling is ok-ish, but it's one route out of the method where we don't log an audit message at all, which probably would be desirable?

@planetf1 This code is actually original code that was removed as part of this first attempt to fix this issue. I put the behaviour back after getting feedback on the first fix. There is nothing the producer is doing that would cause kafka to throw this.
Good to stick with this for our immediate kafka fix - can consider revisiting with a new connector implementation

I noticed in this method we are using time in 2 different units - around line 39. Seconds for recoverytime, milliseconds for regular sleep time. though handled correctly would be better to use consistent units?
@planetf1 again this code was there , but I'm happy to change it if Mandy agrees.
Good to stick with this for our immediate kafka fix - can consider revisiting with a new connector implementation

I notice the text for this event says the message isn't sent. True in terms of this connector's responsibility, but if queueing occurs further up the stack the message is confusing to the audit log reviewer
